sample.title: Why Japan‚Äôs Economy Is at a Tipping Point
sample.description:
For 30 years, Japan‚Äôs prices were largely at a standstill. Now, a weak yen is changing everything. Here‚Äôs how consumers and businesses are coping with rising costs, and what it means for the nation‚Äôs economic future.

sample.title: Can Trump fire Fed Governor Lisa Cook?
sample.description:
The case of Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook is before the Supreme Court. Their decision will determine how much authority President Trump has over the U.S. central bank, which sets interest rates that influence the future trajectory of inflation and the job market.

sample.title: Meta‚Äôs $2 Billion Bet To Win Over Enterprise Customers
sample.description:
In its latest aggressive AI move, Meta has acquired the intelligent agent firm Manus for $2 billion. The deal underscores Meta‚Äôs pursuit of enterprise dominance as the company faces mounting pressure to justify its massive AI infrastructure costs. However, the acquisition has sparked immediate backlash, with long-time Manus users retreating from the platform following the announcement. CNBC‚Äôs Julia Boorstin explores the high-stakes implications for Mark Zuckerberg as he warns investors that 2026 will see a significant surge in capital expenditures.

Produced and Edited by: Andrew Evers
Reporting by: Julia Boorstin, Stephen Desaulniers
Senior Director of Video: Jeniece Pettitt
Animation: Emily Park
Additional Footage: Getty Images

sample.title: Why Tariff Refunds Might Not Lower Prices
sample.description:
If the Supreme Court rules the tariffs are illegal, the refund process could become a lengthy back-and-forth between courts. Meanwhile, consumers are unlikely to see price drops as businesses deal with cash flow crunches. CNBC's Lori Ann LaRocco breaks down the three likeliest scenarios and why businesses will still be left waiting for their money.

Produced, Shot and Edited by: Charlotte Morabito
Reporting by: Lori Ann LaRocco
Animation: Jason Reginato, Emily Park
Addition Production Support: Isabel Iino, Andy Cedeno
Senior Director of Video: Lindsey Jacobson

sample.title: How Anthropic quietly took on OpenAI
sample.description:
Daniela and Dario Amodei left OpenAI five years ago to form Anthropic.

Anthropic‚Äôs revenue has grown 10x annually for three straight years, with 85% coming from business customers ‚Äî the inverse of OpenAI‚Äôs consumer-heavy model.

sample.title: Why Automakers Want To Power AI Data Centers
sample.description:
With EV sales faltering and forecasts lowered, automakers are looking for ways to sell the batteries they are making. CNBC's Robert Ferris breaks down how and why automakers including General Motors and Ford are investing in a new industry.

Producer: Robert Ferris
Editor: Natalie Rice
Animation: Jason Reginato
Senior Managing Producer: Tala Hadavi

sample.title: Wells Fargo CEO on Trump's call for a credit card rate cap
sample.description: Wells Fargo CEO Charlie Scharf told CNBC on Thursday a broad 10% credit card rate cap would be ‚Äúa real problem,‚Äù warning it could lead to a meaningful reduction in available credit, though he praised the Trump administration‚Äôs focus on affordability and willingness to engage in conversations to "get to the right answer."

sample.title: OpenAI chair Bret Taylor says AI is 'probably' a bubble, expects correction in coming years
sample.description:
Bret Taylor, co-founder of the artificial intelligence startup Sierra, said Thursday that AI ‚Äúprobably‚Äù is a bubble that is causing both ‚Äúsmart money‚Äù and ‚Äúdumb money‚Äù to fund competitors at every layer of the tech stack.

Taylor, who serves as the chairman of OpenAI‚Äôs board, said he expects to see a correction over the next few years and the free market will ultimately determine where the value is and which AI players have the best products.

sample.title: Berlinale festival director warns of 'major threat' to film industry
sample.description:
Twenty-two films, from a reflection on ageing starring Juliette Binoche to a Japanese anime feature and a historical drama with German indie actor Sandra Hueller, are among the diverse contenders for the Berlin Film Festival's top prize next month. But Tricia Tuttle, Berlinale festival director, warned that "there is a major threat to the industry, and I think there has been for a few years, but when I raise my fist and do a battle cry, I do it with great optimism."
 
#berlinale #film #movie #cinema

sample.title: Is Canada leading the global resistance against Trump? | The Global Story Podcast
sample.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney seemed to challenge Donald Trump in a speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos this week, declaring that ‚Äúthe old world order is not coming back‚Äù and urging fellow ‚Äúmiddle powers‚Äù to come together. 

In response, Trump said Canada gets ‚Äúa lot of freebies‚Äù from the United States and ‚Äúthey should be grateful‚Äù.   

After striking a major trade and tariff deal with China ‚Äì the US‚Äôs rival superpower ‚Äì is Carney emerging as the leader of a global resistance to Trump? And does he have an alternative vision for the world? 

Tristan Redman and Asma Khalid speak to Lyse Doucet, the BBC‚Äôs chief international correspondent.  

New episodes of The Global Story are released daily. If you‚Äôre in the UK, listen on BBC Sounds. If you live outside the UK, listen on BBC.com or wherever you get your podcasts. 
https://link.mgln.ai/the-global-story...

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news

#Trump #Davos #Canada #BBCNews #Carney

03:54 What did Mark Carney say at Davos?

Donald Trump launches 'Board of Peace' with world leaders | BBC News
sample.description:
US President Donald Trump said his 'Board of Peace' would work with the United Nations, despite a leaked document suggesting it might be designed to replace it.

Founding members of the body, including Argentina's Javier Milei and Hungary's Viktor Orban, sat beside Trump as he touted his administration's achievements on peace.

Jared Kushner, the son-in-law of President Trump, also took to the stage to promote US plans for the re-development of Gaza, including seaside high-rise buildings on the current Gaza Strip.

Trump ended the ceremony by describing himself as a "real estate person at heart".

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog 

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Trump #US #Gaza #BBCNews
